Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A pan-Arctic, storm-by-storm isotopic investigation of the influence of Arctic sea ice on precipitation - a crucial link in the coupled climate system
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will quantify the relationship between the ice-free area of the Arctic Ocean and surrounding seas, and evaporation and precipitation in the Arctic region. The methodology uses isotopic compositions of storm-by-storm precipitation samples, pan-Arctic meteorological data, and numerical modeling. Precipitation samples will be collected at nine Arctic observatories, and by three high schools in Greenland. Samples will be analyzed for D/H and 18O/16O ratios. The track of a given storm will be reconstructed using reanalysis data and a Lagrangian trajectory algorithm. The moisture sources are then localized, and the δ18O, δD and d-excess of the source vapor are calculated using the sea surface temperature, relative humidity and wind speed. The sea ice area transected by each storm will be obtained using high-resolution satellite products. A two-dimensional (2D) model of the atmospheric moisture cycle will be used to compute the isotopic composition of precipitation for each storm at each site using reanalysis values of meteorological variables at the times and regions identified by the Lagrangian back trajectory, and assuming a range of sea ice concentrations. The sea ice concentration that best fits our isotopic measurements is then compared with the satellite sea ice data. The isotope data will thus yield, via the 2D model, the sensitivity of Arctic evaporation and precipitation to ice area. The project will yield a quantitative understanding of the links among sea ice, and moisture sources and amounts of Arctic precipitation, which comprise an important part of climate dynamics on a wide range of time scales. The results will be pertinent to the interpretation of ice core data, ice age dynamics, sudden climate change, and global warming. This project also intends to integrate research with education and outreach, which will directly benefit participating Arctic communities. The project aims to improve community understanding of how climate change research is done, by providing Arctic students with new knowledge and skills, and by inspiring them to pursue advanced studies. At the same time, the PI's will benefit from learning traditional methods of observing, categorizing, and forecasting weather and climate from the communities participating in the study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of California, Merced contribution to the project "Collaborative Research: A pan-Arctic, storm-by-storm isotopic investigation of the influence of Arctic sea ice on precipitation - a crucial link in the coupled climate system" provided FLEXPART atmospheric air mass history simulations for the iiSPACS stations.

The results of these simulations are freely available online via the following link:

http://niflheim.nilu.no/atp/fbar

The simulations provide information on the air mass hitories for measurements taken at the iiSPAC locations. Several products are available including Total Column and Surface resident times as well as Potential Emissions Sensitivity plots.

An exaple Potential Emission Sensitivity plot for Summit, Greenland is shown in Figure 1. 

These results have been used in the following publications:

Chang, R. Y.­W., Leck, C., Graus, M., Müller, M., Paatero, J., Burkhart, J. F., Stohl, A., Orr, L. H., Hayden, K., Li, S.­M., Hansel, A., Tjernström, M., Leaitch, W. R., and Abbatt, J. P. D (2011). Aerosol composition and sources in thecentral Arctic Ocean during ASCOS.  Atmos. Chem. Phys.  (11),  10619. DOI: 10.5194/acp­11­10619­2011

Hyvärinen, A­P. , P.Kolmonena, V.­M. Kerminen, A. Virkkula, A. Leskinen, M. Komppula, J. Hatakka, J. Burkhart,Stohl, A, P. Aalto, M. Kulmala, K.E.J. Lehtinen, Y. Viisanen, H. Lihavainen (2011). Aerosol black carbon at fivebackground measurement sites over Finland, a gateway to the Arctic.  Atmospheric Environment. 45 (24), DOI:10.1016/j.atmosenv.2011.04.026

Sandy Ubl, Martin Scheringer, Andreas Stohl, John F. Burkhart, Konrad Hungerbuhler (2012). Primary source regionsof polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) measured in the Arctic.  Atmospheric Environment. 62  397. DOI:10.1016/j.atmosenv.2012.07.061.

Sjostedt, S. J., W. R. Leaitch, M. Levasseur, M. Scarratt, S. Michaud, J. Motard­Côté, J. F. Burkhart, and J. P. D.Abbatt (2012). Evidence for the uptake of atmospheric acetone and methanol by the Arctic Ocean during late summerDMS­Emission plumes.  Journal of Geophysical Research. 117 (D12303),  .DOI: doi:10.1029/2011JD017086.

VanCuren, RA; Cahill, T., Burkhart, JF., Barnes, D., Zhao, Y., Perry, K., Cliff, S., McConnell, JR (2012). Aerosols andtheir sources at Summit Greenland – First results of continuous size­ and time­resolved sampling.  AtmosphericEnvironment. 52  82. DOI:10.1016/j.atmosenv.2011.10.047

Kramer L. J., Helmig, D., Burkhart, J. F., Stohl, A., Oltmans, S., and Honrath, R. E.: Seasonal variability of atmospheric nitrogen oxides and non-methane hydrocarbons at the GEOSummit station, Greenland, Atmos. Chem. Phys. Discuss., 14, 13817-13867, doi:10.5194/acpd-14-13817-2014, 2014. 

Further, through the UCM contributions to the iiSPAC project, a tool for the analysis of FLEXPART model output has been developed. This tool is released under GNU GPL and is available via:

https://github.com/spectraphilic/reflexible

reflexible is a complete rewrite of the pflexible module that was orginally written to work with FLEXPART model output. The new design goals of reflexible will drive significant changes from the prior module but provide greater flexibility.

The reflexible module is being developed to provide an unified data analysis tool for working with geophysical model data. FLEXPART tools will be the initial target group, but other models (WRF, ENKI hydrologic model, etc.) are included in the development plans.
